column1: thumped on the thigh pad - good evidence of bounce already
nudged out to backward square leg to get this innings up and running
outside off, a bit of early swing in evidence
once more, probing away in the corridor
line and length outside off, but Markram won't be drawn
good delivery, nipping off the seam this time and through to the keeper
a hard-handed poke outside off, getting the feel of bat on ball
much fuller length, speared into the toes and deflected down the leg side
good line and length, very tight to off stump and full too. A well-judged leave from Markram
three slips in place as Markram leaves alone once more
very full length, a bit of late in-dip into the toes. Negotiated with a late adjustment
dangled outside off on a full length, Markram contemplates the drive but thinks better of it, letting a leaping delivery pass harmlessly through to the keeper
full length, angled into the legs from over the wicket, squeezed to midwicket
through to the keeper as Elgar continues to line it up and let it go
back of a length, no stroke offered
a tumbling stop down the leg side this time from Paine
banged in short, a bit of looping bounce from back of a length, Elgar drops the hands and sways inside the line
poked into the covers, not a lot of footwork, but then he rarely needs any
over the wicket, full length outside off stump, solid defence back down the track
fully forward and drilled into the covers. Doesn't quite reach the rope but that's a first sign of intent
wider on the crease, angled back into the bat, blocked back down the pitch
outside off, through to the keeper with good carry

edged and gone! Markram is trapped on the crease by a beautiful length, angling back into the right-hander. Caught in two minds, and he pushed with hard hands as a last resort. Smith at second slip did superbly, diving low to his left to scoop up the chance!
beautiful line and length to welcome the new batsman, angled in, shaping away, forcing Amla to think hard before leaving alone
lifting length outside off, probing work from Starc, as Elgar strides forward before leaving alone
nip off the seam, thumps the thigh pad
right up to the toes, and clipped firmly through midwicket. That's a more confident stroke, filleting the gap and getting the scoreboard moving
a loud yell of 'no!' as Elgar leans forward to defend
another short ball, fizzing through with pace and bounce
solidly onto the front foot, and pushed to cover
sliding down the leg side, Amla attempts a flick but can't connect
a bouncing bomb of a delivery outside off, Amla strides into position then left alone
squeezed through the covers as Hazlewood over-pitches a fraction. A fat outside-edge as Amla leans forward
pushed onto the back foot and blocked
not entirely to the pitch of the ball once again as Hazlewood's awkward length has Amla in two minds once more
sliding down the leg side
sweetly driven, and a good tumbling stop at mid-off. Elgar is timing it well now
left alone outside off stump
through to the keeper with more encouraging lift. If this bounce remains when the shine goes off the new ball, this will be a fine contest
outside off, and through to the keeper once more
into the toes, tucked firmly out to deep midwicket
speared into the toes, well dug out
full length, a hint of swing, nudged back to the bowler
caught in a bit of no-man's land once more, Amla closes the trapdoor in good time
more solidly onto the front foot, meeting the full length with a fuller face
a swishing pull around the corner, not especially short but tucked around the corner
round the wicket from Hazlewood, left alone on the new angle
tighter line to the left-hander, angling back in from round the wicket. Blocked
tweaking down the leg side and helped on its way
striding forward, meeting the turn on the half-volley, and worked into the leg side
fuller length, Amla eases forward to turn the ball out to midwicket
more air this time from Lyon, dipping outside off, and driven compactly into the covers
on the pads, nudged around the corner to short fine leg
faster and flatter, pushed out to cover
on the back foot, and blocked back down the pitch
solidly into line to defend on off stump
decent pace, back of a length, tailing back into the right hander
solid defence on the back foot
bouncer, Amla ducks
sliding into the pads, and chiselled down the leg side
sharp pace again from Cummins, but Elgar isn't ruffled as the ball fizzes through
nudged into the leg side, working with the turn
squeezed out to the leg side with combination of bat and pad, short leg stretches but there's no chance there
leaning forward, head over the ball, defended solidly outside off stump
good delivery! Sharp turn from a fuller length, and skids rather than bounces too. Amla is back on his stumps as he defends late
more comfortably worked off the back foot to the leg side
width, and cut out to point with no great timing
full and inswinging, driven with a bit of fat inside-edge, out through midwicket
lined up on off stump, and blocked back down the pitch
shoulders arms
Amla's best stroke of the morning! Leaning onto the back foot, not especially short, but pulled with placement and intent out through backward square leg
lined up on off stump, solid block back down the pitch
very full once more, Amla drives with lots of top hand, digging the ball out from his toes and picking out mid-on
outside off, pushed on the up into the off side
width outside off, Elgar leaves alone with minimal footwork
striding onto the front foot, blocked once more
solid defence
probing line and length, Elgar remains watchful in defence
up on the toes to block back down into the pitch
through to the keeper once more
worked into the leg side, right behind the line
on the pads, flicked uppishly through the leg side. Picks the gap well to keep the score ticking
head over the ball, nudged into the leg side
round the wicket, defended back down the pitch
outside off, Elgar flinches as the ball fizzes by, but manages to haul his bat out of harm's way
over the wicket, turning down the leg side, and helped on its way
lots of air, dipping outside off and biting towards the stumps. Blocked
flicked in the air but just short of midwicket! Amla was across through the line too soon and nearly scuffed his stroke
too short, too wide, faster and flatter and firmly slapped behind point. Warner does well to dive and intercept on the rope
pushed onto the back foot, driven on the up to cover
full length, defended under the batsman's nose, and that will be drinks
oof, that's a beauty from Cummins on the resumption, a touch short and wheeching past the outside edge as Amla prods at it off the back foot
lines this one up better, driven from back in the crease through cover for a couple
length, 140kph and nibbling back on off stump, Amla shows it a straight bat block
in the channel, left alone as he moves across
pitched up, 143kph outside off, driven into the covers
slightly overpitched and Elgar gets forward to punch crisply into a gap for a couple more
length, rising up outside off, Amla dabs it down
touch short and Amla blocks softly into the off side, scampers through for the single
goes round the wicket, 135kph and defended from the crease
length ball, 140kph and Elgar prods it into the covers
straighter line, defended to the leg side
angled in and Elgar's bottom hand takes over as he crabbily blocks into the on side
ooh, princely stuff, Amla cracks Cummins through the covers, like a headmaster dismissing a miscreant pupil from his sight. Dreamily driven for four
short, 140kph and sliding down the leg side
slightly back of a length and worked down to the leg side
twonk! Four more for the Mighty Hash! Too full from Cummins and he's drilled to the cover boundary again
bangs the ball in short by way of a riposte, Amla sways serenely underneath
dug in short again, left alone
length ball, 137kph and coming in with the arm, tucked to the leg side
banged in, the bumper seems to surprise Elgar and there's some excited yelping from the Australians as he hoicks it into space towards backward square leg.... gets away with it
back of a length on off stump, comes across and defends
fired in straight and clipped towards mid-on
lets this one go in the corridor
rising from a length, splice-juddering stuff but Amla quells the threat as he gets into line
fullish in the channel and driven, wide of mid-off but without timing
short, huffing and puffing as it flies through to the keeper, Elgar stays in his house
full, 143kph and wanged down in the channel of Blink 182, there's an appeal as Elgar fiddles at it... but I think the sound was bat hitting ground, Starc not interested and neither was Nigel Llong
gets a bit straighter with his line and worked to the leg side
speared into the pads, Elgar is comfortable dealing with those and clips a single behind square
hammers the bouncer but it's leg side and Amla ducks it without fuss
nicely played, that's a lovely shot to bring up the SA 50, Elgar caressing a drive through mid-on and it teases the chasing fielder all the way
Elgar comes across and taps a single into the gap
length on off, defended back to the bowler
touch shorter, 136kph and zipping through as Amla waves his bat away
back of a length outside off, again no need to play
Hazlewood hangs the ball out wide, touch short but again Amla isn't interested
Starc gambols to the crease and then hurls down a wide delivery that keeps going away, no stroke required or offered
tip and run into the covers, they make it home as the throw comes in
length, 137kph and thudding into the pads... but it pitched outside leg and they amble the extra
digs in the bouncer, it's a bit too high to trouble Elgar as he shuffles into line and ducks
fired down and left alone again
drops short, there's width for Elgar to swing his blacksmith's hammer, crumped through backward point and it races away
pushed into the batsman, Amla waits for it and tucks a couple off his pads through midwicket
touch short, lets this one go in the channel
pitched up, tempting Amla outside off, he shows it an immaculate straight balde
good length, fourth-stump line, 143kph and blocked
ooh, gets him closing the face a touch, nibbling to thud into the leading edge as Amla plays across the line
full, 143kph and stunned towards extra cover on the drive, snapped up by the fielder
angled in and clipped for one off the pads
length, 140kph and shaping a touch on off, Amla blocks back to the bowler
some seam and bounce as Amla gets tucked up, the ball rapping the thigh pad - high and leg side, though
sprayed across the right-hander, Starc scrambling the seam and his line, no stroke offered
straighter, back of a length and worked towards midwicket
banged in, defended from the crease around the line of off stump
good length on middle and off, pushed warily back down the track
oh yeah, yello, that's a shot... Elgar creams a drive through the covers, overpitched from Marsh and seized upon, no issue with the aesthetics there
tightens his line again, tapped to leg
woof, four more, oozing class with a shot down the ground this time! Too full and Elgar butters his crumpets again
pitched up and slashed through cover point, runs flowing now... although this one won't quite go all the way. Elgar looking pomped up
length ball, Amla calmly dabs it to the leg side
yeesh, Starc reminds everyone he's still got it, comes screeching in with a 142kph yorker, Elgar has to chop down in the nick of time as the ball tails in
gets into line and taps to the off side
tight line, Elgar blocks on the stumps
touch straighter, tapped to the on side
counterpunch from Elgar now, driven firmly on the up, using 141kph for his own ends and he picks up three through the covers
dug in, 140kph and rising outside off, Amla rides it and cushions the ball to backward point
goes short, the ball whizzes through at chest height as Elgar rocks back
touch full and tapped back towards mid-off
Marsh goes round the wicket, hammers the middle of the pitch, again Elgar can see it early and duck
in the channel, lets this one go
fuller length, 135kph and plinked into the covers, no timing on the drive
touch short in the channel and left alone once more
full, 143kph outside off stump, Amla mistimes a drive to mid-off
angled across in the channel, not coming back and he can leave it alone
this keeps low, bobbling through wide of the stumps as Amla ignores it
fullish length on the stumps, Amla pokes it defensively to mid-on from the crease
dug in short, climbing through to the keeper as the batsman weaves out of the way
back of a length over the stumps, 140kph and jabbed to midwicket, Amla calls 'No!' - and that will be lunch
round the wicket, solid line and length, blocked into the off side
angling into the pads from round the wicket, helped on its way out to midwicket
pushed onto the back foot, an awkward spring-loaded length from Hazlewood, but blocked down into the crease
sliding down the leg side, wafted on its way around the corner
inducker from over the wicket, nipping into the pads and tucked to leg
through to the keeper once more
round the wicket, dabbed into the leg side
nudged down through the gully, soft hands riding the bounce. But that's a threatening length from Cummins, keeping Elgar on his toes
much fuller, squirted wide of mid-on, who stretches to his right to intercept
outside off, and through to the keeper once more
tucked out to square leg to keep the board ticking
firmly onto the front foot, head over the ball, bat tucked into the front pad. Solid
tight line on off stump, jabbed out to the leg side with a closed face on impact
zoinks, banged in short and that flies over the keeper! No issue with the carry for that one
another short ball, leg-sided this time, and more easily gathered
ooh, close! Elgar misjudges one, coming in on the angle from round the wicket, tries to leave the ball on length at the last minute, and chops down into the crease
hurried once more on a full and probing length, firmly blocked in the end
poking the arm-pit with another bouncy length ball, nudged behind square. That was a feisty over, if successfully negotiated
short and angling into the left-hander. Elgar ducks
much fuller, slightly wider, Elgar pushes with flat feet, out into the covers
squeezed out through third man, finds the gap with aplomb, opening the face on impact
wider line, no stroke offered
top shot, a fraction too short, Elgar was loitering on the back foot, and hauls a firm pull through midwicket to bring up a fighting fifty
dancing onto the back foot, firmly pushed out to cover
firmly behind the line of the ball, pushed down to mid-off
angled in from wide on the crease, Amla works around the front pad to tuck the ball into the leg side
another yawning leave outside off stump

banged in short, and Amla holes out to fine leg! You can't quite say that was coming, but Hazlewood has earned that, he's found a threatening line, a consistent length, and the surprise bouncer does the trick. Amla attempts to flap it off his eyebrows, but it gets big on him, takes a top-edge, and loops to Cummins!
striding out to meet the full length, firmly drilled to mid-off
fully forward, head over the ball
onto the front foot, pushed to cover
stabbed out to cover with shuffling feet
that's a tremendous strike! Angled into the toes, and AB just wafts an on-drive to the fence! Oodles of bottom hand, swinging up into the stroke, and clocking the pants out of it. Ridiculous talent
attempted hoick into the leg side. But a very cultured hoick, of course, for this is ABDV
caught a touch on the crease by the fuller length, and squeezes a clip through backward square
banged in short, ducked
driven on the up, a bit of a closed face takes the ball out to midwicket, and up comes the 100
outside off, tempting the drive, but Elgar is having none of that
banged in short, another duck
fuller length, testing front foot and back. Defended

slapped to point and dropped! Nathan Lyon, saw it all the way in, but it hit the heel of his hand and burst through. Elgar was done in by the extra bounce, and couldn't keep his stroke down. Big let-off!
another sharp lifter, attacking the arm-pit and fenced down to the leg side
quality strokeplay! Tenderised through the covers, on the up and in the slot! Nothing remotely wrong with the length, but the timing was out of this world!
big stride, bigger leave outside off
outside off, climbing through to the keeper once more
pushed back onto the stumps, worked with a roll of the wrists into the leg side
outside off, deflected to the covers
cramped for room on an ambitious back-foot drive, but middles it well enough to be fielded at cover. AB has a mood on, sit tight!
punched through long-off! That's Elgar's slot, tight line on off stump, but just the right length for him to spring forward like a hungry hippo and snaffle the ball through the line!
banged in short, clips the helmet, loops to the fielder ... half an appeal but there was no bat in that. Quality bowling though! Elgar was comprehensively beaten on the pull
on the back foot, and worked to the leg side
zipping over the shoulder, lots of heat in that delivery but less bounce. Elgar turns turtle
down the leg side
solidly onto the front foot to defend
nip from a full length. AB removes his bottom hand in a statement of surprise

wallop! Short and wide, and de Villiers climbs over the covers with alacrity! A pistol crack of willow and a followthrough reminiscent of Darren Gough at Sydney in 1994-95! He's enjoying himself out there...
tighter and fuller. Solid defence on off stump
outside off, no stroke offered
outside off, AB leaves alone with a will-you-marry-me bend of the knee and raise of the gloves
no stroke again, AB swivels as the ball goes by, as if to fully compute the line, length and late swing
angled across the left-hander, who defends with a late stab of the gloves to the off side
banged in short, ducked with ease, down the leg side
outside off, clobbered off the back foot, in the air for a while, but through the gap at gully!
nurdled to the leg side. Sharp running
wide outside off, a big leave
yorker length, but outside off, stabbed back down the wicket
spawny! A fine delivery, climbing off the deck and nipping off the seam, de Villiers played with loose hands, stabbing at the ball as it climbed past him, and straight through the gap at third slip!
slip and short leg lurk as this one tails into the pads
head over the ball, nudged into the leg side
worked off the pads to midwicket
on the toes, and nudged out to the leg side
head over the ball, smothering the lack of spin
forward and pushed hard to the on side
tucked to midwicket
down the leg side
sharp delivery! Short, but brutishly short, clangs into the forearm as Elgar takes evasive action from an awkward back-of-a-length
full and hostile, Starc is straining for reverse swing  but no great signs just yet. He's quick though, as Elgar is rapped on the pads...
outside off, good leave, disdainful almost, as he barely flinches from his stance
up on the toes, poked to the off side
round the wicket, lobbed up on the stumps, defended
flighted, straightening and tapped down
tossed up and it drifts across the right-hander, driven into a gap for one
uses the feet, Elgar waltzes out and blaps four through the covers! Assertive stuff, playing with the turn rather than closing the face - which has been his downfall previously
this spins through to Paine, nicely bowled and acknowledged by the batsman
floated up full, comes across and lines it up in defence
back of a length on middle and leg stump, AB jumps across to block
in the channel, 138kph but he can probably leave this one length
pitched up and de Villiers punches firmly off his pads, picks out mid-on
slanted across, 139kph and tailing away - maybe a fraction of reverse? - but wide enough to leave
short and rising, 142kph in the channel, steered towards point
back of a length, de Villiers straightens up and taps to extra cover from the crease
whipped this time, Elgar on the charge again! Gets to the pitch and then whips the ball through midwicket with bottom-handed gusto
flatter and defended
floated up as Elgar comes across on off
now he goes downtown, smoked all the way! Lyon shakes his head in frustration, he gave the ball some air and Elgar grabbed it, heaved the ball over the rope at long-on!
tossed up, presses forward to block on off stump
quicker delivery, this time he drops back and shows it a straight bat
now AB cashes in, short from Starc and he clips it off his hips with timing and precision
oh, that's even more dismissive, a wafted flip high over midwicket and away! The ball didn't get up that high and de Villiers just whacked it merrily for another boundary!
short of a length and worked off the hip, into a gap for a couple more - SA cross 150 in the process
dot ball, ABdV jumps across to defend
in the channel outside off, 140kph and whistling through as de Villiers leaves
lets another length ball slide through wide of the stumps
lovely bowling, this dips and turns past the outside edge as Elgar reaches for it
pushed through and he lines this one up to block
flat delivery on off, tapped away
pushed through, Elgar defends on off stump
tossed up a bit slower and Elgar again drops back to block to the off side
quicker ball, 93kph and squeezed out on the stumps
short again and worked away towards deep midwicket with some comfort, they come back for three
over the wicket, banged in short, 138kph but Elgar ducks
pitched up and sliding on to the pads, Elgar flicks it firmly behind the close catcher and it races away for another boundary
in the channel outside off, nothing doing
banged in short, pace just 133kph and again he can evade it easily enough
short of a length around off, gets on top of the bounce to block
Lyon stays round the wicket to AB, defended down towards short leg
pushed through and worked into a gap at midwicket
flighted, met on the front foot with a solid block
comes across to defended on off
drops short now and Elgar, having been ballroom dancing down the pitch, now drops back to hammer a cut for four
angled in with the arm, tapped to the leg side
fullish around middle and leg stump, tapped towards mid-on
length ball, AB comes across to defend
slightly wide, rising in the channel as de Villiers steps back and across and pushes into the covers
short of a length, 136kph and left alone outside off
Cummins is looking for reverse swing away from the right-hander, again he's comfortable leaving
pitched up, 137kph and driven firmly along the carpet to mid-off - a maiden, from Patty C, his first of the day
tossed up and dinked back down the ground coming forwards
flighted, de Villiers shuffles across and defends
AB comes down and pushes another single back past the bowler
this skids on with the arm and comes off the inside edge of the bat
flat on the stumps, worked back to the on side and Lyon goes across to field
quicker still, on off stump and punched to cover
good length, shaping away a fraction, no stroke from AB
short ball, this time he sways back out of the way
back of a length, 142kph and defended around the line of off
hits the pitch hard, 140kph and de Villiers starts to close the face a touch, the ball pings to mid-off
full and buzzing in at the stumps but de Villiers is ready for it, keeps his balance and rams four off his pads through midwicket
follows up with the bumper, ABdV limbos out of the way
round the wicket to Elgar, goes very full and wide, there's some reverse swing, too, but no need for the batsman to chase it
length ball, 132kph and steered towards point
touch short and straightening in the channel outside off, Elgar lets it go
dug in and there's good carry as the ball flies through, no stroke forthcoming
slings down a full-bunger, chopped out towards point
good length, nipping away as the batsman comes across...but MMarsh had overstepped
fullish, driven wide of mid-off and Elgar wants one, de Villiers looked a bit slow in taking off but manages to get home as the throw comes in at the striker's end
good length, 131kph on the pads and deflected behind square
length outside off, 135kph and de Villiers whisks it through midwicket for a single
round the wicket, pitched up and clunked towards mid-on as Elgar comes across and closes the bat face
full length, gets him pushing forwards, tapped back
length ball, pushed into the covers
dug in short, that's coming through at an awkward height but Elgar manages to get his bonce out of the line
length ball on off, Elgar handles the danger (not literally) once again
left alone in the channel
length, not much in the way of lateral movement, again de Villiers lets it go
touch shorter and punched towards extra cover off the back foot
good length, 124kph on fourth/fifth stump and ABdV gets on to the front foot, dabs the ball late down into the off side
pitched up and drilled through cover, releases the shackles after some tight bowling, David Warner hurtles after it and does terrifically well to prevent a boundary

round the wicket, full outside off and Elgar throws the hands, slashes a thick edge beyond the reach of second slip! And the ball flies for four, to rub it in! Smith looks aghast - he made a great, leaping effort but couldn't get a hand on it
over the wicket, lobbed up and tapped away
flighted but drifting a touch leg side and the ball deflects off the pads, runs wide of the keeper for four leg byes
fullish, coming out quite nicely for Smithy, dinked back to the bowler
full and flighted, tapped to extra cover
oh, has he slipped one through...? De Villiers seemed to play around a legbreak, it hit him on the back thigh, so maybe height a question; no review off his own bowling from Smith
flat legbreak outside off and driven towards point going back - which takes us to tea with SA looking pretty comfortably placed
outside off on a full length, clunked to cover
ooh, good ball! Beautiful length, bounce and movement too, and this one bursts past a slightly startled back-foot waft outside off
fuller length, tighter to the top of off stump. Stout defence back down the line of the ball
short, and lifting sharply over Elgar's gloves as he sways out of line
drilled through the covers! Beautiful balance, stretching onto the front foot and pounded into the gap. Quality strokeplay
down the leg side, a flick off the pads, and gathered at backward square
round the wicket, dropped onto a probing length, pushed into the off side with solidity
not quite there for the drive, but Elgar is lured anyway, meeting the ball a touch late but getting away with it
banged in short, not interested in this one
worked off the pads with a closed face
short and Elgar ducks without complete conviction, hauls his shoulders further into their shell as the ball doesn't get up so much
right under the nose to defend
round the wicket, outside off, poked into the off side
back of a length from round the wicket, de Villiers clips cleanly into the leg side to bring up the 100 stand
shoulders arms once more, angled into the stumps but passing harmlessly by
very wide on the crease from round the wicket, creating a big angle back into de Villiers' stumps, who blocks with a full face
driven on the up as Starc spears one into the toes, a squeeze out through fine leg

that's a superb way to bring up a hundred! Slightly leg-sided, but shovelled with glee through wide long-on! Ungainly as ever, but you cannot quibble with the timing of that stroke, or the commitment of the innings. Top class, and he's given Australia plenty to ponder
width outside off, left alone with intent
outside off, a hint of outswing, no stroke offered
outside off, slapped hard off the back foot but straight to point
through to the keeper with no stroke offered
full length, punched on the up to the leg side
pushed onto the back foot, right behind the line of the ball

back of a length, and that's a dismissive flick off the hips! Up comes the half-century with a filleted four through backward square. The ball wasn't especially leg-sided, but AB makes the angle with nimble footwork and astonishing bat speed
full length, outside off, an angled stab into the covers
short and sharp! Elgar thought about ducking, but the ball didn't quite get up and he ended up yanking his head out of harm's way instead
tailing into the pads, squirted into the leg side
full length, wide line, no stroke this time
outside off once more, angling in but there's no real shape on this old ball today. Left alone with ease
driven on the up out through midwicket, he's stood tall to that length all day, and finds the gap once more
just stunning poise and timing! A half-volley maybe, but what a response. The full face of the bat, no followthrough whatsoever, just rattling speed off the face of the bat through long-off
left alone
width once more outside off, no stroke this time
clipped off the pads, out through fine leg
pushed back onto the stumps, blocked to the off side
on the back foot, hauled out through midwicket, just picking the ball up as if it was thumbing a lift, and placing it at its destination. Cheers mate, much obliged...
full face of the bat in defence
a squirty edge through third man! They all count. This time beaten on the angle back into the stumps, but soft hands prevent the edge from flying up into the cordon
that's a powerful clip off the toes, but Hazlewood stands his ground at midwicket
sliding down the leg side
clumped back to the bowler
a bottom-handed biff into the leg-side, very Gooch-esque in fact, solid base and a big wind-up, but can't beat mid-on
outside off from round the wicket, a hop across the crease to leave alone
through to the keeper with extra nip off a good length
very full, wide line, a bottom-hand flog out to point. Very Graeme Smith. All the Grae(ha)mes are coming to the party now
poked to cover off the back foot

in the air and gone! Newlands is stunned into semi-silence... a full length, AB strides onto the front foot and rather yorks what should have been a half-volley, getting through the shot too soon and rifling a simple chance to Warner at mid-off. What a let-down for the crowd, what a let-off for Australia!
outside off, a hint of outswing, fenced to the off side
a horrible leg-side swinger, no stopping that for Paine, and no wide either. Very harsh...
tailing into the left-hander, there's suddenly reverse swing on display
flicked behind square to get off the mark
picks the gap in the covers with a well-timed punch, avoiding point but inside of cover. Nurdling of the highest order

up onto the toes, and that's excellently played, down through third man, turning what looked like an awkward lifter into an excellent run-scoring deflection. Good dive on the rope to save the boundary
very full, speared into the toes
lifting off the deck, thumps the splice as Faf takes his bottom hand off the blade to control the defensive block
fuller length, attacking the base of the stumps, and blocked
short, ducked
wide on the crease, and that's a tremendous drive, leaning into the angle and timing it sweetly to the rope
standing tall in defence, blocked back down the pitch
round the wicket, tossed up, dipping into the crease. Blocked
shaping into the pads, tucked to the leg side
big stride, lots of air from Lyon, luring the big shot, but nothing doing yet
blocked on the front foot, just dangling it out there...
a bit of turn from a good length, Elgar stretches forward
on the back foot, nudged off the hip
banged in short, no stroke offered
defended on the back foot, right behind the line
width outside off as Cummins bangs on in short. No stroke this time
battered hard into the covers, that was creamed, but Warner stood firm to intercept
outside off, and through to the keeper

edged and Faf falls! Another fine delivery from Cummins, nipping away late and du Plessis' bat was just in the wrong place at the wrong time, drawn into a stroke then unable to resist when the ball was no longer where he had lined it up. A sharp high take at third slip, and suddenly Australia are back in the contest
leaning forward to block
pushed to the off side
round the wicket, looped into the blockhole, and defended
squared up in defence, very watchful now that his flowing partners have perished
driven, a touch hard-handedly, into the covers. Gets away with it
solidly onto the front foot. Blocked once more
ooh, lovely line. Welcome to the crease Temba! Full length, nip off the seam, beats the edge
outside off, through to the keeper
pushed firmly out to cover
hops across the crease to work a single to fine leg
sharp once again, lifting past the outside edge as Elgar is made to hop
left alone on a wider, fuller line
stretching onto the front foot, turned to the leg side
rotating the wrists on impact, tucked to the leg side
on the back foot, nurdled to square leg
blocked on the back foot, outside off
a turn of the wrists, and a single to mid-on
tossed up and blocked on the line of middle and off
outside off, climbing through to the keeper
lovely bowling, ghosting past the edge as the ball angles in and holds its line. Bavuma does well not to touch that one
brilliant from Cummins! Pushes Bavuma back into his crease, finds some extra nip on a good length, and a squared-up batsman sends a simple edge into Smith's bread-basket at second slip!
round the wicket, fired in the channel outside off and de Kock slaps a couple through point to get going
back of a length, 137kph and rising through as he throws the hands up
coming back in, but the line was wide enough for QdK to leave alone
nervous moment around the ground, Elgar skipping down and then driving a bump ball back into the hands of Lyon - no c&b this time
flat on off, shows it a dogged straight bat
angled in and turned to the leg side
tossed up and Elgar makes a bit of room to steer one in front of square
pushed through on off stump, de Kock leans on a block
quicker ball, played from the crease, lined up well enough in defence
fullish around off, Elgar takes his bottom hand off as he defends
shorter length, pushed square from the crease
dug in and Elgar has to ride the bounce, keeps it down as the ball flies towards the cordon
fullish, 139kph in the channel, Elgar watches it impassively by
goes over the wicket now, dangles the carrot - but Elgar the mule won't be biting
snorting short ball, smell the leather... but Elgar nods it through and sets his jaw for further crease occupancy
tossed up on off, the ball skids on as de Kock starts to open the face
shuffles into line and blocks
ooh, that's taken off, leaping past the shoulder of the bat from a length, turning away from de Kock as he hung back and was beaten
pushed through around off stump, steered into the off side
comes forward and punches down the ground
flat and zipping on as de Kock shows it a straight bat in defence
round the wicket, banged in short and a touch leg side, Elgar flinches out of the way
back of a length, 137kph and clipped towards mid-on form the crease
flung very full and wide in the channel, Elgar doesn't sniff at it
pitched up around off stump, driven to mid-on and he quickly turns around after thinking about the one
tapped through the off side for one

short ball, de Kock swishes at a pull - but only manages a thin nick to the keeper! Another old-ball breakthrough for Australia, another to Pat Cummins, whose four-wicket salvo has left SA thoroughly winded here! De Kock was tempted by the gap at square leg but was perhaps done for pace, tickled an under edge through to Paine
angled in from round the wicket, defended on the stumps
turned down to the leg side
tossed up and pushed in front of square on the off side
uses the feet and drives one down the ground
over the wicket to Big Vern, who waits and works the ball with the spin to get off the mark behind square
back around, sliding on with the arm and skimmed to backward square leg
over the wicket, holding its line outside off as Philander hangs back
yowzer, that's a nifty nut, reversing away as Philander feels for it and is beaten in the channel!
length outside off, manages to cover the line this time and jab square
short and climbing as Vern watches it through
dug in, 140kph and this time Philander isn't going to sit and watch, raises the bat in anger and hoicks four over square leg - pounded
another bumper, this time he lets it go outside off
tossed up on off, Elgar closes the front door
pushed through and tapped back down the track
leans on a front-foot block
tossed up around the line of off, Elgar smothers the ball
a touch quicker and he drops the bottom hand off the bat as he jabs it away
this bounces a touch more, hits the splice of the bat as Elgar hangs back
good length in the corridor, left alone
touch short, Philander sits back and clubs a cut for one to the sweeper
full, just a touch overpitched and Elgar eases it down the ground, lovely timing and Josh Hazlewood has to put in a full-length dive to drag it back from the rope
comes across and shows the ball a straight bat
wicket-to-wicket from MMarsh, turned to the leg side
good length, Elgar thrusts forward and keeps it out once more
flighted, played with the spin to leg
tossed up and defended coming across on off stump
big turn fro Lyon, this rags back in and thuds into the pads... in actually fact, that flew off the inside edge, but Philander's body got in the way to prevent it carrying to short leg
tapped down into the off side
floated up and turned to leg on the back foot
gives this a bit more air, Philander props forward and dead-bats is securely
Marsh probing away, stump-to-stump, defended
keeper still up to the stumps, Elgar camps in the crease and defends
goes a touch straighter, jabbed back towards the bowler
length outside off, left alone
oof, 129kph but it pops off a length, past the shoulder of the bat and into the gloves as he feels for it
angled in on the stumps and worked to mid-on
this goes on with the arm and takes the outside edge, but Philander manages to run it wide of slip for a couple
floated up around off stump, defended
tossed up and defended on off stump
flighted, pushed back down the track
lobbed up full around middle and off, Philander leans on it
full length, Philander opens his shoulders but can only bunt the ball to mid-on
angled in towards off stump, Elgar prods it into a gap for one
jabbed down towards point, Philander wants a quick one but a knackered Dean Elgar sends him back in time
and that's why they're sticking with the old ball! Reverse swing does for Philander, just enough movement away to draw the edge - Mitch Marsh bags a wicket, SA continue to wobble towards the close
length ball, straightening a touch and it jumps to hit the splice and loop short of gully!
shuffles across and tickles one into the leg side
round the wicket, dobbed on off and defended
short ball, Maharaj swipes skittishly across the line and top-edges clear of the keeper and slips running back! Doesn't quite go all the way, but he survives
thudding into the pads, they go up for lbw now! But this hadn't quite straigtened enough
length around off, Maharaj prods it away
pitched up, Maharaj lines it up and dinks the ball towards mid-on

oh dear, that's a shocker... SA lose their eighth as Maharaj flubs a catch to extra cover! Brain scrambled by reverse swing and pace? Maybe... Hands hard and foot nowhere near the ball? Certainly. That's a rubbish way to go any time, but particularly when you're team is on the slide and hanging on for the close with a centurion at the other end
Starc greets him with some chin music, steepling bounce as KG nods it through
round the wicket, length delivery holding its line on off, defended coming forwards
touch straighter and he works it fine for a single
goes full on leg stump, Rabada keeps it out
length, 135kph and Rabada plays a correct-looking punch square on the off side
full outside off, stroked towards cover as he gets a stride in
short and this gets big on KG, who thick-edges the ball just short of slip! Smith dove forward but couldn't get there
over the wicket to Elgar, who blocks a length delivery
pitched up and clipped back past the bowler for one
pitched up and driven, nicely played by Rabada and he gets a couple through cover
full length, again Rabada attempts to thrash the ball through the off side, fails to connect this time
length, rising in the channel, steered down towards point
yaroo, spanked for four! Rabada absolutely creams a drive past extra cover, those long limbs unfurling like a carnivorous flower
Hazlewood finds his length in the channel, round the wicket and nipping away
pitched up, met coming forwards with a dab into the covers
this climbs off a length, 131kph and it slams the splice of the bat as Elgar lunges forward, the ball diverts through backward square
shortish, KG jumps back and blocks towards his toes, the ball bobbles wide of the stumps
oof, he takes this on the body, rearing from a length and beating the bat on the inside
hits a length around off stump, Rabada lines this one up
round the wicket, outside off stump, full length, wide line, left alone
stabbed into the covers to get the score moving this morning
tight line, back of a length, hops through to the keeper as Rabada just about avoids playing at the ball
through to the keeper once more
good wheels from Cummins, over the wicket now, angling across the left-hander from just back of a length
right behind the line to defend this one, as Cummins drops short once more. A good aggressive start to his day's work
round the wicket, angling down the leg side, clipped firmly off the hip to fine leg
back of a length, tucked to midwicket
round the wicket, angling into the pads, flicked square once more. Hazlewood just straying in line a touch
banged in short, but the top-edge falls safe! A sharp bouncer, good pace, startling lift, Rabada swings impulsively into the pull but is lucky with his placement
fully behind the line and punched down the ground
a swishing bouncer, and that clears everyone! Over Rabada's shoulder as he has another go, and over the keeper's head too!
outside off, and through to the keeper on a wide line
width and a full length, a touch of late outswing as Elgar stretches for the drive but can't connect
stabbed defence, outside off stump. gathered in the covers
round the wicket, back of a length, really hitting the bat hard as he pushes for the breakthrough. Elgar gets right behind the line
sharp pace again, through to the keeper once more
pushed to cover again
banged in short, Rabada doesn't quite commit to a back-foot block, playing down into the crease
very full, attacking the stumps, dead-batted back down the pitch and that's a sharp, sneaky single as mid-on swoops round
tight to off stump, stabbed out to point and yet another swiftly judged single
ooh, nearly! This one jags back in, and loops off the thigh pad out into the cordon. No bat involved but tricksy movement off the deck
fenced down into the ground off the back foot again.
on the back foot, and a calmly placed pull behind square to keep the strike
top edged but effective! South Africa won't mind that, another bouncer to Rabada, another combative swish across the line, and the keeper has no chance to intercept that!
hoisted with a pleasing report of willow, down to backward square. He's standing up for himself this morning. As if that was ever in doubt
full length, outside off, poked down into the pitch
full once again from round the wicket, another nuggetty stab out to extra cover
on the back foot, lining up the angle into the stumps and blocking into the off side

wallop! Dismissive thump across the line, another short ball, but Elgar was waiting for it this time on the back foot, cracking it in front of square with a de Villiers flourish! That's his highest Test score against Australia
behind the line, pushed to cover
clipped off the pads out to square leg. This is already a very healthy start for South Africa

short again, down the leg side, Rabada falls inside the line and wafts another pull to fine leg. The short ball is the preferred option this morning, but I wonder if pitching it up might be worth considering
outside off again, slightly fuller, defended
very full length, and defended back down the pitch
right behind the line once more
fuller length, behind the line, pushed to the off side
banged in short, Rabada ducks but leaves his forearm in the firing line, a deflection takes it just out of the reach of Paine's fingertips behind the stumps
well bowled, that's a more threatening length, ironically. Fuller, drawing the drive, and beating the edge with late movement

too wide this time, and Elgar frees his arms with alacrity! A crashing cut over backward point and away to the rope! South Africa are motoring towards 300, which was their first objective this morning
punched off the front foot into the covers
well bowled again, nibbling through to the keeper from outside off
top strike! Fuller this time from Hazlewood, but right into the slot for a measured drive through mid-off. Tasty batting
another swishing pull, to backward square. Rabada is playing a blinder here, taking on the short ball and backing himself to connect more often than not
squeezed defence, into the leg side, hopping into line
clipped out to deep midwicket, and up comes the 300. South Africa have righted the wrongs of their afternoon session
solidly blocked on the back foot
more pace, whistling through to the keeper. Australia have been good this morning, but South Africa have been better
another fizzing bouncer, can't connect with a flinched pull
short again, Rabada is pre-empting the bouncer now, and walks inside the line in an attempt to deflect it very fine. Misses out
short once more, Rabada ducks without a care in the world
fuller length, still a fraction short, but it draws a loose poke as Rabada follows the angle outside off. Better from Australia
back of a length once more, and Rabada, with his blood pumping, has another go. Deep backward point in place, and a wide gully
short again, outside off. Rabada ducks again
poked into the on side, calm and composed
banged in short again, outside off, as Rabada drops his hands
short, pulled, safe! Rabada is making his own luck with his aggressive intent, I reckon. Another shovelled pull, a spiralling top-edge, but lands safe at fine leg
turned inside out this time by a better-directed short ball, aimed right at the ribcage
bang! That's an awesome bit of biffing! Meeting the fuller length with an utterly out-of-character thump through the line! Holding the pose and dumping the ball right to the brink of the rope
nip off the deck on a middle-and-leg line, flicks the pad and flies out to point
round the wicket, in the slot, a hard-handed drive, a simple edge to slip! Well, that was uncomplicated
round the wicket, tossed up into the toes, and blocked
dumped over long-off! Well, why not! In the slot and slogged high and handsomely!
width outside off stump, and left alone
edged and gone! A carbon copy of the Rabada dismissal, in the slot for the drive, and tweaking away. Lyon has two in the over, and South Africa's innings is done!
sidles in and pitches short, 127kph and Cameron Bancroft fences it down into the leg side, elects not to run
touch straight again and worked away through backward square leg, they come back for two
nice shape on this, 124kph but it's that ticklish line and length outside off, Bancroft feels for it and gets a low outside edge
pushed down the leg side, no swing and the batsman misses with a flick
good length around off stump, Bancroft blocks it resolutely
touch short again, Philander up above 130kph for the first time, jabbed towards square leg
steams in, hits a length at 140kph straight away, blocked towards mid-on
yowch! This kicks at David Warner, hanging back in the crease and he takes a blow on the arm, the ball then ricocheting into the body - on comes the physio, that's going to ache come this evening
pitched up, inviting the drive and Warner accepts, opens the face a touch and slides a 141kph ball to the rope at deep backward point, easy as you like to get off the mark
fullish on the pads, Warner clips the ball fine and wants two... but the fielder keeps them honest
touch short of a length around off stump, 139kph and not much swing as yet, Bancroft defends
charges in again, over the top of off stump, Bancroft gets his big ol' melon into line and blocks with a straight bat once again
couple more for Warner, who covers the movement across him and steers a couple through the off side
yoinks, this takes off from a length! Philander finds a mini-trampoline buried in the Newlands surface and sends shocks waves through Warner's bat handle as he jumps to fend it away
ooh wee, now he clips the inside edge, Warner not quite forward trying to drive, runs to fine leg
back of a length, 131kph and nibbling in, blocked
good length, curving a touch out of the hand but Bancroft lines it up well and leaves alone
probing away, 128kph on a fourth-stump line, steered down in front of square
length ball angled across, and Warner nearly chops on again! Not really the width to cut but he went at it hard, squirted the ball past leg stump
angling in, 141kph and defended back down the track
excited shouts as Rabada finds the inside edge of the bat, it loops in the air through backward square leg... but there's no one there, Bancroft trots the single
too full, rifled to the cover boundary! Warner climbs into a cover drive, low in his stance and using 141kph to his own advantage
oh, even better, a murderous scyth past extra cover for four! This wasn't a half-volley but he dispatched it via first-class delivery to the ropes

skelped off the pads, three in a row! Morkel gamely gives chase but he can't reel it in, Warner lets his bat do the talking in his battle with Rabada - this could become a proper brawl (within the confines of the Laws, of course!)
ooh, beats the outside edge, some distance between bat and ball as Bancroft feels for it
comes across and defends on off
pitched up and cracked through the covers, Bancroft finds his groove and sends one on a rail to the fence
draws his length back, left alone outside off
intriguing tussle this, Bancroft again left poking in the channel, a genuine play and miss
yeesh, that's close to the timber! Big inside edge from Bancroft as the ball snakes back between bat and pad, flies just past off stump and away for four!
digs the ball in short... and Warner hurls his bat, KABOOM! over fine leg! That has gone miles, high up into the stands - someone is going to have to fetch it!
FETCH THAT! Five boundaries in a row for Warner off Rabada! Just a touch of width and he slashes it through backward point, and you can sense KG's temperature rising!

bowled hiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiim! Rabada lands the decisive blow, up off the canvas and demolishing off stump! This enthralling duel is ended by Rabada slicing through Warner's tentative defence and sending the stump pinwheeling back. An extraordinary innings from Warner, struck on the arm and then responding with a flurry of boundaries before being run through, bowled off stump for the third time in the series
pitched up and angled across Uzzie, who can leave
touch short and jabbed away to the leg side
good pace, 140-plus kph in the channel outside off
gets a touch straight, worked off the pads into a gap at midwicket and Khawaja is off the mark
angled across in the channel, nipping away as Khawaja comes across
ooh, that's close, skates through to the keeper past the outside edge

beaten and struck on the pads, not given but SA decide to review. This dipped across Khawaja and flicked the back pad as he got squared up... but I think that's going to be missing off stump, given the angle from over the wicket. Yep, impact was umpire's call and it was then heading past off stump, always a bit speculative
pitched up in the channel, no stroke this time
gets a touch straight and worked away for a couple
Philander goes knocking in the corridor once again, left alone by Khawaja
heat on this, 148kph and arrowing in at Bancroft, it deflects down to fine leg
pitched up and steered towards point from the crease
tight lines from Rabada, he's not under attack now, 145kph and Khawaja defends on off
oof, that's a spicy meatball, 148kph once again and Uzzie has to bail out at the last moment as it threatens the top of his bonce
on the body, forced through midwicket for a couple
length around off, lines it up in defence
good length, looking for a chink in the armour, Bancroft defends solidly
oh, dreadful running... but the underarm from cover is well off target! Bancroft dropped the ball into the off side but the call left Khawaja struggling for his ground, luckily the throw was poor
in the channel outside off, 128kph and sliding through as Khawaja shoulders arms
down the leg side, flick and a miss from the batsman
tight around off, Khawaja defends
touch short of a length and Khawaja defends from the crease
yoinks, how has he not edged that?! Testing length, 143kph and the ball holds its line, fades past the edge into the gloves as the arms begin to go up...
dug in short, Bancroft sees it early and ducks
back of a length, pushing the speed gun to 146kph as Bancroft attempts to work it off his body
full and straight, 149kph/92mph as Rabada clicks up through the gears but Bancroft plays it well, flicked nonchalantly off his pads and it races away through midwicket
good length on the stumps and tapped down into the off side
back of a length, comes across to block... another front-foot no-ball from KG
gets into line again and defends
good length and he draws Bancroft out, takes the outside edge but he controlled it well for four through gully
more risky running, again Khawaja seems to be on his heels as Bancroft drops the ball into the covers, but Markram can't hit the stumps!

dug in short, Uzzie swivels on the pull... and sends it straight down the gullet of fine leg! Rabada with the catch in front of the stands! More whoops around Newlands as Morkel strikes with his third ball; he's always going to get extra bounce and Khawaja didn't seem to have factored that in, though he usually plays the pull shot well
welcome to the crease Smiffy! Banged in short, 137kph and sliding leg side
length, speared into the covers coming across
another bumper from Morne to finish the over, Smith ducks it
rising from a length, scuds into the pad, think it was high though... they take the leg bye behind square
avast and belay! Smith smokes a square drive for four! It was full and wide and asking to be hit, really - so Smith did
hits a length around off, Smith defends

criminy, that's a beast of a ball, 148kph and it hits Smith in the armpit! He was moving across and looked like he wanted to leave but the ball wasn't in the mood to comply, Smith stuck in the crosshairs and struck a stinging blow
Rabada oversteps again, charging in looking for that extra yard
touch short outside off stump, Smith jabs it down towards backward point
fuller, searing pace at the stumps, but Smith thrust his bat down and keeps it out to end a ferocious hour of Test match cricket!
trundles in and hits a back of a length outside off, climbing through to de Kock as Bancroft lets it go
touch short and wide, 135kph and left alone once again
coming back in this time, bouncing at a nasty height, Bancroft phlegmatically closes the face and blocks
whoosh, that's gone to the fence, 145kph in the channel and full enough to invite the drive, flies uppishly but behind point and away
goes wide and fires the ball in, short of a length and tucked to leg
banged in, rising to crunch into the splice as Bancroft gets up on his toes, well defended down into the off side
good length, rising sharply as Smith pongos across his stumps and defends
ripper, 148kph and past the outside edge! Rabada slips back into his groove, glides in and hammers the pitch short of a length, Smith was trying to force off the back foot and is beaten
touch fuller, hits 150kph/92mph now, Smith lines it up and blocks on off
length ball in the channel, Smith drives with a flourish, all cubist angles but no timing this timing, rolls to extra cover
fired in straighter, a heat-seeker on the front pad, Smiffy manages to squirt it away through backward square leg
slightly wide, climbing off a length and left alone
dug in short at the rib cage, Smith hops across and blocks
touch back of a length outside off, left alone
Morkel attempts to bounce Smith, who isn't interested in cross-batted shots, for now

extra lift, Smith fences at it - and sends a simple catch to gully! Smith can't believe it, Morkel looks like he can't believe it... but you'd better believe it, Australia's captain is gone, his first single-figure score since the Adelaide Ashes Test! The pace was good but Smith doesn't usually waft at those if he doesn't need to. All eyes on Rabada but Morkel is the man to take the head of the snake
length, slightly leg side and he dobs it down from the crease
slightly back of a length, 143kph and Marsh covers his stumps in defence
and he's thrumming away on a good length immediately, fish-tailing in a touch as Bancroft blocks
touch short, Bancroft wants to tip and run but again he's left his partner in the doo-doo! A direct hit from Bavuma and Marsh was struggling, but the throw misses by a whisker!
on the stumps and tucked to the leg side
wicket-to-wicket attack from Big Vern, lined up in defence
length ball, 126kph and attempting to nip to across the southpaw, tapped away to the on side
in the channel, 129kph/80mph and winking flirtatiously at the batsman as he comes across and shoulders arms
that's a fiendish line, short enough to leave but you've got to hold your nerve, the ball jagging back in as Bancroft does so, shoulders arms
fuller, nibbling in a fraction, clips the inside edge as he reaches forward, gets a single down to fine leg
hits the pitch hard, the ball nips away and judders the outside edge, flies low towards Elgar in the gully... but this one didn't carry, squirts away for a single
dug in back of a length outside off, Bancroft rides it and drops the ball into the covers, this time they don't risk the run
bosh! Bancroft takes on the short ball and clouts it over square leg, meaty connection and that bounds away into an unguarded part of the field
back of a length, 143kph and blocked on off
angled across the bows, Marsh happy to let those go
fuller and closer to off stump, testing his patience and Marsh does have a nibble this time, stroked towards extra cover
length ball, comes across and defends on off
ambles in and pushes the ball through in the corridor of bamboozlement, slightly short and Marsh leaves
another length delivery around off stump, defended
straighter line, 126kph on middle and leg, tapped towards midwicket
short, 143kph and rising outside off, this time Bancroft judges his nudge into the covers well
round the wicket to Marsh, pitched up and entices the drive, the ball flies through backward point - managed to keep on top of it and they pick up three
flicked away off the pads, Philander does terrific work on the rope at fine leg to prevent four
pitched up and punched through mid-off, couple more to Bancroft's tally
woof, 140kph and sizzling into the keeper's gloves, Bancroft beaten as he groped in the channel!
overpitched, lovely timing from Bancroft, pinged back down the ground... Morkel got a hand on it and had Marsh diving for his ground, but the ball diverted past the stumps and away for four
length around off, 131kph and tapped down in front of square
yeesh, how close was that to the top of off? Tight lines, looking to give the batsman a thorough frisking, but Marsh judged it well
and again, 130kph on a rail just outside off, Shaunie has to watch it closely, leaves again
this is Scrooge McDuck tight from Philander, the ball snaking back but he's just a fraction short and Marsh can let it go
straighter, jabbed down to the on side
good length and nipping away appreciably this time, doesn't make the batsman play
yikes, that's cut him in half! Back of a length and jagging back a ridonculous amount, flies over off stump as Bancroft tries in vain to get his bat down
short of a length, lets this one go
on the stumps, 133kph, Bancroft shows it a straight bat in defence
oh, keeps low, hits the front pad as Bancroft walks across... but missing leg stump, I think, might have clipped the bat, too
round the wicket to Marsh, who defends
slightly too full and Marsh bullets a drive to the cover rope for his first boundary - neat and compact, like a barber applying a swift buzz cut
comes across and misses with a flick
length in the channel, 127kph and nibbling away, Bancroft decides not to feed the fishes
pitched up and Bancroft drives, nearly drags on to his stumps! We've seen him go that way before, but this time the ball squirts to fine leg
touch short, the ball swerves away from over the wicket as Marsh leaves
scuttling through low, length delivery around off and it hits the toe of the bat as SMarsh lines up a block
sliding on to the pads and tucked away square for one
round the wicket, short of a length, 136kph and nudged down to fine leg for one more
angled in, climbing to deflect off bat and the thigh pad as Bancroft flicks to leg, there's man at leg gully but he can't cut it off and that boundary takes Australia into three figures
short of a length outside off, left alone

short, wide and crunched to the point boundary, that's a splendid way to go to fifty! Bancroft sees it early rockstars the cut for four, TV right out of the window, there. Brings up his third Test half-century
pitched up and punched through cover to the sweeper
tip and run into the covers, this time Bavuma isn't quick enough to trouble them
over the wicket, lobbed up and blocked on off stump
tight lines, patted away coming forwards
this skids through a bit quicker, he drops back and chops down on it
flighted on off stump, Marsh props out to defend
tossed up, wheeling away rhythmically already, blocked from the crease
slightly flatter and Marsh goes back, turns down into the leg side
short of a length, 139kph outside off, Bancroft ignores it
ooh, there's the line, shaping away a fraction as he draws Bancroft into an indeterminate push, beats the edge
back of a length, line slightly wide and he can leave this time
short, angling in and chopped down into the off side form the crease
pitched up, Bancroft steps out smoothly and steers a drive through backward point, nicely done and he gets another boundary
good pace and bounce in the channel, left alone once more
onto the front foot, drilled into the covers
lovely footwork, lovely timing! Sashaying to the pitch and pounding through the covers!
big stride forward, a slip is lurking but met with a full face
aggression again, advancing down the pitch, looking for the lofted drive but settling for a clip to mid-on
advancing to meet the pitch of the ball, pushed back up the pitch
fuller length, met with a straight bat, head over the ball, nudged to mid-on
ooh, feisty bowling, back of a length, climbing past the edge with a bit of late movement. Bancroft stays inside the line
shoulders arms once more
nip off the pitch, raps the back pad
outside off, and zipping through to the keeper. A bit of nibble off the deck now, and good pace from KG
hooping outswing but Bancroft picks the wider line early, and watches his drive onto the middle of the bat. That's quality
tight line, fuller length, dabbed defence into the covers and they screech through for the single
round the wicket, dabbed into the gap
poked into the covers
head over the ball, meeting the full length with a clip to wide long-on
more flight and bite, big grip from outside off stump, but firmly pushed away
drilled into the covers but what a stop from Bavuma! Diving full stretch to cut off a certain four. He's lightning
clipped off the pads, in the air for a moment, but dies in front of short mid-on
round the wicket, angling into the left-hander on a full length, and stabbed out to point
sharp running into the covers, bat and pad together as Rabada probes away on a full length
fired down the leg side, Marsh has a waft but can't connect
crunched to short cover as Marsh meets the full length with a straight bat
round the wicket once more, point is on point to gather a squirty defensive push
nip back into the left-hander! Marsh was halfway committed to a push outside off and just about changed his mind as the ball jagged viciously back into him. Ungainly but well played in the end
down on one knee, a subtle lap-sweep behind square, using the pace of the ball to excellent effect
tossed up from round the wicket, a full face of the bat in defence
chiselled firmly off the toes, and that whistles through midwicket. Bancroft is playing with extreme fluency now
full face of the bat again, pushed to midwicket and Maharaj is miffed that there's a single on offer there
clipped uppishly to mid-on, easy pickings for Australia at the moment
better bowling, dragging the right-hander forward for a full-faced defensive push
round the wicket, attacking the hip and dabbed to the leg side
banged in back of a length, nip off the deck and solid back-foot defence
on the legs, tucked to short midwicket
firm block to the off side
angling back into the pads, as Bancroft stands firm in defence
nip off the deck once more, but from back of a length. Bancroft sights it early and lets it go
solidly behind the line
solidly blocked
clipped to leg, but no way through there
a compact drive into the covers, neatly played
gathered in the followthrough as Marsh gets behind the line
clipped on the up, into the leg side and they scamper through
outside off, through to the keeper with a flourish of a leave-alone
that's sumptuous! Over-pitched outside off stump, and a rifling cover drive, played it late, weight leaning through the ball, and timed to perfection
a big yawning leave outside off
stoutly blocked back down the track
a yawning leave outside off stump
nip off the seam, but on a wide line. An unruffled leave-alone
a hint of outswing on a wide line, stabbed out to point
stretching onto the front foot, and firmly placed to mid-off
another leave outside off, lining up the outswing and letting it go
back of a length and curling outswing, Bancroft is beaten but makes a meal of it. Half a yard fuller and he could have been in business
takes the edge this time, but going down all the time, and clean through the vacant third slip! A moral victory but more runs to the total. The 150 is up
stands tall in defence, blocked back down the pitch
tight line, angling into the left-hander, stoutly blocked on the back foot
splice-jangling bounce from a full length! Marsh rides it well, taking off his bottom hand to control the shot

Marsh chases the wide one, and there's the breakthrough! ... 300 Test wickets as well, and what a key moment to do so. The bounce pushed Marsh back on his heels, and he wasn't in control as he nicked to the keeper
big nip off the seam, as Mitch Marsh lines it up and misses it by a mile
outside off, and through to the keeper, more jag and bounce from a good length
fully forward and dabbed into the covers
stretching onto the front foot, and solidly blocked
that's a jaffa! Hooping swing from Philander, his trademark line and full length, shaping down leg then bending past the off stump with nip off the seam. Misses the edge by a whisker
this one tails back and holds its line. Left alone
another leave-alone. A lot resting on Bancroft now
drawn onto the front foot, and defended into the covers
wider line, keeps a touch lower as it swings through to the keeper
left alone on a very wide line
outside off, too wide once more to draw a stroke
banging out a consistent line and length, but consistently too wide to tempt a stroke
left alone again
this is a tighter line! Rears at the gloves from an off-stump line, and flicks the thigh pad, en route to the slip cordon. Excitement, but no bat involved
no stroke once more. A very Harmison-esque over there. Lots of bounce, intermittent threat
big stretch onto the front foot, worked down the ground
outside off, and through to the keeper
big stride once more, angled defence into the off side

celebrappeal from Big Vern, and with good reason, that's plumb! He doesn't bother looking at the umpire as he sets off towards the cordon, tight line, nibbling back into Bancroft's front pad. He has reviewed, but more in hope than expectation. Yep, smashing middle and leg.
fullish, around off stump and prodded defensively to the on side
pitched up n the corridor, Paine watches it through
oi vey, he's right on the money to start with, straightening off the deck and climbing past the outside edge
length ball, this nips away a touch and Marsh can leave more comfortably
shortish, 130kph a foot or two outside off, no stroke offered
back of a length and zipping through as Marsh goes back and shoulders arms
good line, gets him thinking about the shot, just leaves him enough
whoosh, past the bat again, 137kph and this drew Marsh into a genuine push before seaming through to de Kock. Morkel on it from the get go
pitched up outside off, tapped towards mid-off
lets this one go in the channel
130kph wobbler in the channel outside off, Paine demurs
short and rising to be blocked over off stump... and Nigel Llong calls him for overstepping
length outside off, Paine shuffles across and leaves
tap-tapping away in the channel, Paine leans on to the front foot, sniffs the breeze and shoulders arms
angling in a touch more, blocked on off stump
ah, and that helps break the dam, Marsh stepping across and stroking a controlled drive through the covers to get off the mark
shortish, 135kph outside off stump, left alone
lovely delivery from Morkel, pitched up a bit further and then decking away as Marsh feels for the drive and is beaten
slightly wide this time, 138kph and left alone
oh, done by another jaffa! Maybe just a fraction too short, allowing the ball to straighten past the edge as Marsh thrust at it from the crease... but that's textbook Morkel
dabbed into the covers, they chance the single against Bavuma again... but the throw is wide of the stumps! Think Paine might have got home anyway

gottim, that's pitch-perfect Philander on his favoured cabbage patch! Not much Marsh could do about that ball, a femme fatale on off stump, it kisses the outside edge and curves through to the keeper - chewed up and spat out. SA taking a grip here
shaping away on a seductive length once more, Cummins lets it go
nearly gets his man! Straightening just enough on off stump, takes the edge but flies low towards the cordon
slightly straighter and blocked into the leg side
probing away, line and length in the corridor, no stroke
sends down another in-out nibbler but Cummins watches it carefully by
touch full from Morkel, 137kph outside off and Paine clips a drive to the fielder
shortish, comes across and taps the ball away
good length, angled in and holding its line, Paine shoulders arms
Morkel is giving nothing away for free here, again it's watched through hawkishly outside off
nipping away off a length, slightly wide and Paine can leave well alone
dropped down towards point and despite an initial call of 'No' they make the single comfortably
bit of width, Paine shuffles across and spanks a drive to the cover sweeper
Vern and his ball-on-a-string seek out the top of off, Cummins covers it
gets him fiddling in the wind this time, slightly back of a length and Cummins can leave but there's magnets in these deliveries and he's this close to nicking off
gets a little straight, worked off the pads for a couple, Cummins off the mark
full, curling away, 130kph and driven but without timing to mid-off
sliding down the leg side, this goes quick a long was a Cummins flicks at it, de Kock does well to get a hand on it and prevent more than a bye
drops in the bumper, not seen too many of those from Morkel today but it's well directed, Cummins takes evasive action
in the channel, back of a length and Cummins can stay inside the line
that's a beauty again, touch short and jagging away as Cummins goes fishing and is beaten
fired in this time, worked across the line
bangs in the short ball, Cummins ducks hastily
finishes with a ripsnorter, reversing away from the bat from back of a length - good luck hitting those
releases the pressure straight away, dragged down and Paine seizes on a bit of width to hammer four through backward point
tossed up further towards the front foot and defended to extra cover
chipped back past the bowler! Maharaj threw himself across but couldn't get to it, struck pretty firmly coming forwards by Paine
flighted, spinning away outside off, Cummins leaves
tossed up and met on the front foot, defended softly back down the track
gets a it more dip, straightening on middle and off, Cummins blocks doughtily
drops short and Paine swivels to bat a couple away on the pull through square leg
oof, that's not far off, bit of an injudicious swipe from Paine, on his heels and beaten for pace
short of a length, 144kph and sizzling through in the channel outside off as Paine throws his hands up
slightly short again and this time Paine dabs one into the covers
banged in, 143kph and veering back at Cummins like a Vespa cutting through traffic, fended down to fine leg for one
in the channel, again Rabada is a fraction short and Paine can usher it through
tossed up and blocked on off stump
flighted, Cummins plants the front foot to defend
sliding on a touch flatter and the ball pops low off the inside edge, short leg lurking
pushed through outside off, Cummins goes back to cut but finds point
presses forward to block on the stumps
loped up full and Cummins taps the ball down the ground, accepting the offer to keep the strike
excellent line, lifting from a good length, beats the bat as Cummins hangs back
short ball, the batsman hunches down in his bunker
length, jagging back in at 145kph, Cummins blocks into the covers
full in the channel, 141kph and played neatly square on the drive, Maharaj scuttles across to cut it off and prevent a run
dug in back of a length and whistling through outside off stump
this comes back in menacingly to clip the pad, heading down the leg side, thought
tossed up and pushed square on off stump
Cummins leans into another solid forward defensive
flighted, stroked back to the bowler
tossed up straighter, presses out to block
Maharaj gives it some more air, again Cummins taps it away cautiousl
angled in full on middle and leg, nudged to the on side and Maharaj hops across to field
short ball, dropped down into the covers and they give Bavuma another chance to pull off a sharp run out... but he underarms wide of the stumps
comes across and steers the ball square

that's the line, big outside edge and it's snaffled at third slip! Rabada reverses the ball away at a fair old lick and it's too good for Patty C, de Villiers plunges to his left to take the catch and Australia are seven down!
round the wicket, length ball curving away, 138kph but wide enough for Starc to ignore
touch short, angled in and prancing past the bat as Starc dangles it hopefully
nip-backer this time, Starc pre-meditates his leave... and it practically shaves off stump on its way past! Rabada has his hands on his knees, close but no cigar
flat outside off, Paine drops back and cuts forcefully towards backward point
tossed up and tapped back down the track
wheeling away, Paine comes across to defend
steered into the off side
floated up and patted back down the track again
given some flight around middle and leg, Paine pushes it watchfully away to end a maiden
short of a length, Starc goes after this one, bit top-edgey but he picks up his first runs over cover

reversing away, Starc stretches for the ball, steered low into AB's bucket hands! Another excellent catch from third slip, diving forwards to scoop a thick edge, giving Rabada his third and denting Australia further
oof, he takes this on the heart! Short and slamming into the body as he drops the hands... but we know Lyon's got ticker
rising in the channel, fences at the ball as is beaten
another snorting lifter outside off, Lyon can't law bat on those
pitched up a bit more and Lyon counters, hoicking the ball clear of mid-on for three to get off the mark
full length in the channel, Lyon clubs it in front of point for a couple more
teasing delivery, fullish and seaming enough, beats Lyon's airy waft

dropped! Or, at least, missed... Philander has hurt himself here, having dived full length for a catch running across from mid-on. Lyon scooped the ball high in the air, towards the midwicket area, and Philander couldn't quite get a hand on it - he then seemed to jar his knee, possibly wind himself, too
short of a length, 135kph outside off, left alone
pitched up and dabbed behind square, de Villiers hared up from the cordon and had a chance to run out Lyon, he was well short but the throw was off balance and wide!
through to the keeper, did that go under the bat? Lyon was late on it, the ball might have kept low... but on we go
pitched up and pushed along the carpet to mid-off
dug in short and Paine whirls on the pull, slaps it away behind deep square leg for four
curving through outside off, lets it go
short of a length, 144kph and climbing like Lizzie, George and Ralph to be taken high up by de Kock
fires this one in straighter, Paine gets into line
back of a length, 139kph and left alone in the channel
Morkel goes full, stump-splattering length, swatted away calmly by Lyon
bouncer now, swung away h-i-i-i-i-i-i-i-i-i-i-i-i-i-i-g-h in the leg side... but it's wide of Rabada, who runs around the rope but won't get to it as the ball plops into the outfield
pitched up, 138kph and Paine tries to withdraw the bat, ends up deflecting the ball into the turf
tight, off-stump line, defended on the back foot
steams in and sends the ball down on a shapely line in the channel, Paine lets it go
short and there's room for Paine to cut, gets a couple to deep backward square as Maharaj tumbles after it
outside off, and through to the keeper
stabbed down to third man, and that'll help no end
backs away as Rabada goes wide on the crease to create an angle, and cracks firmly to point, just short of the fielder
a flying edge and dropped by Amla! A massive wipe through the line from Lyon, a very thick edge, flying high to the left of first slip who reaches high but can't cling on!
very full and tailing into the toes, no appeal as Rabada thumps the pad, down the leg side
leaning forward, stabbed into the covers
a dirty dobbler outside off, actually a pretty good line and length, and uneasily wafted away
short and wide, and slapped hard to deep point
back of a length, crunched hard through the off side, that's a solid bit of ball-striking
short, wide, pies. Lyon gleefully thwacks another cut-drive through the covers
that's more like it, tailing in with the reverse swing, and demands a respectful block on middle and off
flipped off the pads to the leg side. That experiment was a resounding failure
clears the front leg and lines up a chaotic slog through the line. Short leg flees to the boundary, even if the ball doesn't
round the wicket, Lyon walks inside the line and pulls compactly to backward square
leans forward, poked into the covers
that's a magnificent drive through long-off! Hitting the ball on the up, not remotely to the pitch of the ball, but what an eye. Slotted
a dismissive slap through point! Well, well, these are vital runs. Like Rabada this morning, Lyon is taking the positive approach to the short ball, leaning back and flinging the bat!
dropped by de Villiers at third slip! Another slash at a good length delivery, and AB tumbles back but can't cling on as the ball arrives at pace. A rarity
chopped off the back foot to point, Amla fumbles but quickly recovers
